flow.context: Bectali is a Home Care Specialist (housekeeper) at Haustay Vacation Rentals — one of three in-house cleaners doing turnovers across ~50-60 coastal North County San Diego properties. She is NOT the decision maker for tooling. The buyers are Nick Foster (Founder/President), Elisa Foster (Founder/VP), or Agostina Baldi (Director of Hospitality, ex-Vacasa). Haustay runs Streamline PMS + PriceLabs, promises a clean-then-inspect process after every guest stay, and leadership has publicly stated they want 'automation on all processes in order to scale.' The goal of this call is to be respectful of Bectali's time, learn how inspections actually work on the ground from someone who lives it, and get referred up to whoever owns that process — most likely Agostina, Nick, or Elisa.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Bectali — I work with a few property managers down in North County San Diego on their turnover inspection workflows. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Bectali is a housekeeper, not a decision maker. Be warm, casual, respectful. The real goal here is intel about their inspection process and a referral up to Agostina, Nick, or Elisa. Don't pitch hard.

branches.label: Who is this? / What's this about?

heard_no.label: THEY HAVEN'T HEARD OF YOU
heard_no.say: Ha — I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well honestly, the reason I'm calling — I'm not even sure if you'd be the right person for this, but I figured you'd know better than me. We work with property management companies on their turnover inspection process — the photo documentation, catching stuff that gets missed after cleans. Who on your team typically owns that side of things?
heard_no.note: Don't try to sell a housekeeper. Immediately pivot to figuring out who owns the inspection workflow. She knows exactly who checks her work.

branches.label: That would be Agostina / our Director of Hospitality
That would be Nick or Elisa / the owners
I'm not sure / I just do the cleaning

heard_yes.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone on the operations side. What did you hear?
heard_yes.note: Rare path but if she says yes, someone at Haustay may have mentioned RapidEye. Listen carefully for who brought it up — that's your real contact.

branches.label: They mention a name or context

who_is_this.label: THEY WANT CONTEXT
who_is_this.say: Yeah totally fair — it's Sam Parks, I'm with a company called RapidEye. We work with property managers on the inspection side of turnovers. Honestly I'm not even sure if you'd be the right person — I was hoping you could point me in the right direction. Who on your team handles the inspection process after cleans?
who_is_this.note: She's confused, not hostile. Quickly clarify and pivot to the referral ask. Don't waste her time pitching.

branches.label: That would be Nick or Elisa

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — sounds like you're in the middle of it. Would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow? Or honestly, if there's someone else on the team who handles the inspection side, I can reach out to them directly so I'm not bugging you.
bad_timing.note: She's probably between turnovers or on-site at a property. Respect it completely. Try to get a name before hanging up — that's the real win.

reschedule.label: RESCHEDULE
reschedule.say: Perfect — I'll try you again tomorrow. Before I let you go, real quick — who on your team typically handles the inspection workflow? Just so I'm talking to the right person.
reschedule.note: Even on a reschedule, try to get a referral name. That's the real prize from this call.

got_agostina.label: REFERRED TO AGOSTINA
got_agostina.say: Agostina — she's the Director of Hospitality, right? Perfect, that's exactly who I should be talking to. Do you happen to know the best way to reach her — is she at the office today or is she usually out at properties?
got_agostina.note: You already know Agostina Baldi is Director of Hospitality, ex-Vacasa. Confirming her title shows you've done homework without being creepy. Try to get a direct number, email, or transfer.

branches.label: She's in the office / try the main line
Not sure how to reach her

got_founders.label: REFERRED TO NICK OR ELISA
got_founders.say: Got it — Nick or Elisa. That makes sense since they run everything. Do you know if one of them handles the operations side more? Like who would deal with the inspection and turnover process specifically?
got_founders.note: Try to narrow to one founder. Nick is President (operations), Elisa is VP (hospitality/scaling). Either works. Also listen for whether Agostina is the real day-to-day person.

branches.label: Not sure / just try the main number

got_nick.label: REFERRED TO NICK
got_nick.say: Nick — perfect. Would you mind giving him a heads up that Sam from RapidEye might reach out? I'll keep it short with him. What's the best way to get him — is nick@haustay.com still the best email, or should I just call the main line?
got_nick.note: You know Nick's email is nick@haustay.com. Confirm it casually. Getting Bectali to mention your name to Nick turns the next call from cold to warm.

branches.label: Confirms email or gives contact info

got_elisa.label: REFERRED TO ELISA
got_elisa.say: Elisa — awesome. Would you mind letting her know Sam from RapidEye might reach out? I promise I'll keep it quick. Is the best way to reach her through the main office number?
got_elisa.note: You know Elisa's email is elisa@haustay.com and direct number is 858-215-2551. Don't reveal all that — just confirm the path naturally.

learn_from_bectali.label: LEARN ABOUT THEIR PROCESS
learn_from_bectali.say: Totally get it. Hey — honestly since you're the one doing the turnovers, you'd know this better than anyone. When you finish a clean, do you guys take photos of each room? Like is there a checklist or an app you use, or is it more of an informal thing?
learn_from_bectali.note: This is gold. Bectali lives the turnover workflow daily. If she describes their photo/checklist process, you'll know exactly how to position RapidEye when you reach the decision maker. Listen more than you talk.

branches.label: Yes we take photos / use a checklist
I don't really know / can't talk about it

dig_into_process.label: THEY TAKE PHOTOS OR USE CHECKLIST
dig_into_process.say: Got it — so you're already documenting everything. That's actually great. Do you know if anyone reviews those photos after you submit them? Like does Agostina or someone go through them, or do they mostly just sit there unless there's a problem?
dig_into_process.note: You're confirming the core pain: photos get taken but reviewing them across 50-60 homes is the bottleneck. This intel is ammunition for the decision-maker call.

branches.label: Not really / only if there's an issue

someone_inspects.label: SOMEONE ELSE INSPECTS
someone_inspects.say: Oh interesting — so there's a separate inspection step after the clean. Who does that, is that Agostina's team or does one of the founders do spot checks?
someone_inspects.note: Haustay's site says they inspect after every clean. Find out who actually does it and how. This person is the one RapidEye helps most.

branches.label: We kind of all pitch in

no_formal_process.label: NO FORMAL PHOTO PROCESS
no_formal_process.say: That's actually super common — most companies I talk to are in the same boat. The photos either don't happen consistently or nobody has time to go through them all. Hey, I don't want to keep you — who would be the best person to talk to about that side of things? Would that be Agostina, or more Nick and Elisa?
no_formal_process.note: No formal photo process is a strong RapidEye fit signal. Note this for the decision-maker call. Now pivot cleanly to the referral.

photo_review_process.label: PHOTOS ARE REVIEWED
photo_review_process.say: That's really thorough — most companies aren't that dialed in. Hey I really appreciate you sharing that. I don't want to eat up your whole day. Would it be cool if I reached out to whoever runs that review process? Who would that be — Agostina?
photo_review_process.note: Even if photos are reviewed, the volume across 50-60 homes is still the pain. Note these process details for the decision-maker call.

photo_review_gap.label: PHOTOS AREN'T REVIEWED CONSISTENTLY
photo_review_gap.say: Yeah that's exactly what I hear from most teams — the photos get taken but nobody has bandwidth to actually go through fifty-plus properties worth of photos every week. That's literally the problem we built RapidEye to solve. Hey — I don't want to keep you from your day though. Who on the team would be the right person to talk to about this? Agostina, or more Nick and Elisa?
photo_review_gap.note: This is the perfect pain confirmation. Write it down — it's your ammunition for the decision-maker call. Now get the referral and wrap up.

pivot_to_referral.label: PIVOT TO REFERRAL
pivot_to_referral.say: Totally understand — I appreciate you humoring me on this. I know this probably isn't your department. Who would you say is the best person to talk to about the inspection and turnover process? I'm guessing someone on the operations side?
pivot_to_referral.note: Clean pivot. Don't make her feel bad for not knowing. Just get a name and move on.

soft_objection.label: SOFT OBJECTION
soft_objection.say: Totally get it — and honestly, you might not even be the right person for this. I really just need to get to whoever handles the inspection side of things. Would you know who that would be? I'll leave you alone after that, I promise.
soft_objection.note: She's a housekeeper saying 'not interested' — she doesn't have the context to evaluate the product. Don't argue. Just ask for the referral and respect her time.

branches.label: Try the main number or office
Still no / wants to hang up

got_referral_name.label: GOT A REFERRAL NAME
got_referral_name.say: Perfect — and just so I don't go in totally cold, would you mind giving them a quick heads up that Sam from RapidEye might reach out? I'll keep it super short with them. I really appreciate your help, Bectali.
got_referral_name.note: Lock in the warm intro. Even a casual mention from Bectali to Agostina or the founders makes the next call 10x easier. Write down the name and any context she gives.

agostina_contact_info.label: GOT AGOSTINA'S CONTACT INFO
agostina_contact_info.say: That's super helpful. And would you mind giving Agostina a heads up that I might call? I'll keep it really quick with her. You've been awesome, Bectali — thank you.
agostina_contact_info.note: Write down whatever contact info she gives. Then wrap up warmly. Bectali is a potential internal champion if this goes well — she can vouch for you being respectful.

agostina_try_main.label: TRY MAIN LINE FOR AGOSTINA
agostina_try_main.say: Got it — I'll try the main line. Hey before I go, would you mind mentioning to Agostina that someone named Sam might call about the inspection process? Even just a casual mention would help a ton.
agostina_try_main.note: Main line is (858) 522-9127. The warm intro request is the most important ask here.

ask_for_warm_intro.label: ASK FOR WARM INTRO
ask_for_warm_intro.say: Would you be able to just mention my name to them next time you see them? Even just 'hey, someone named Sam called about inspections' — that way I'm not a total stranger when I reach out. I'd really appreciate it.
ask_for_warm_intro.note: This is the soft ask. Even a passing mention converts the next call from cold to lukewarm. Don't push if she's uncomfortable.

transfer_to_agostina.label: BEING TRANSFERRED TO AGOSTINA
transfer_to_agostina.say: That would be amazing — thank you so much, Bectali. I really appreciate it.
transfer_to_agostina.note: If you get transferred, you're about to talk to the real target. Switch gears completely. Agostina is Director of Hospitality, ex-Vacasa, owns QC. Open warm since Bectali just connected you.

transfer_failed.label: TRANSFER DIDN'T CONNECT
transfer_failed.say: Hmm — looks like she might be away from her desk. Hey Bectali, if you're still there — do you know if there's a direct number or email for Agostina? Otherwise I'll just try the main line again later.
transfer_failed.note: Don't lose the progress. Try to get a direct contact for Agostina before hanging up.

agostina_live.label: AGOSTINA PICKS UP
agostina_live.say: Hey Agostina — Bectali just connected me. I'm Sam Parks with RapidEye. I work with a few other property managers in North County San Diego on their turnover inspection process. Have you heard my name tossed around at all?
agostina_live.note: You're now talking to the real decision influencer. Agostina is Director of Hospitality, ex-Vacasa, owns QC across 50-60 homes. If she's warm, go to pain trigger. This is the call within the call.

agostina_heard_no.label: AGOSTINA HASN'T HEARD OF YOU
agostina_heard_no.say: Ha — I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call — I work with another property manager in a pretty similar spot to you guys. About sixty homes, in-house cleaning team, and they run this clean-then-inspect process after every turnover. Sound familiar? The problem was their team was taking photos but nobody had time to actually review them all. Stuff was slipping through — a stain on a couch cushion, a missing throw blanket — and it'd show up in a guest review or an owner call instead of getting caught at the turnover. We built something that plugs into the photos your team's already taking and uses AI to flag anything that's off — damage, missing items, staging that doesn't match the baseline. No new app for the cleaners, no workflow change. Would you be open to taking a look at some point when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue?
agostina_heard_no.note: This is the full pain trigger tailored to Agostina. Haustay promises inspect-after-every-clean across 50-60 homes with a tiny team. The volume is the pain. She came from Vacasa — she knows what breaks at scale. PAUSE after the pitch. Let her react.

branches.label: We already have a process for that

agostina_warm.label: AGOSTINA IS WARM
agostina_warm.say: Yeah for sure — so real quick, what does your inspection process look like right now? After the cleaners finish a turnover, are they documenting in Streamline or is it a separate tool?
agostina_warm.note: STOP PITCHING. Ask questions. You know they use Streamline PMS. Confirm whether photos route through Streamline or a separate app. This tells you exactly how RapidEye plugs in. Listen for pain signals.

branches.label: Wants to know more about RapidEye first

agostina_discovery.label: DISCOVERY WITH AGOSTINA
agostina_discovery.say: Got it. And when something does get missed — like a stain or something broken that shows up after a guest checks in — what happens? Does that come through Tala on the guest services side, or does it bubble up to you first?
agostina_discovery.note: You know Tala is Head of Guest Services. Mentioning her name shows you know the org without being weird. You're mapping the pain chain: cleaner misses it → guest reports it → guest services escalates → Agostina gets the heat. That's the cycle RapidEye breaks.

branches.label: Describes the escalation path / confirms pain
It doesn't really happen that often
That's actually a big issue for us

agostina_brief_pitch.label: BRIEF PITCH FOR AGOSTINA
agostina_brief_pitch.say: Totally fair. So the short version — we plug into the photos your team's already taking during turnovers and use AI to flag anything that's off. Damage, missing items, staging that doesn't match the baseline. No workflow change, no new app for Vanessa or Bectali or Emily to learn. It just catches the stuff that's impossible to catch manually across fifty-plus homes. I'd love to show you a quick demo — I've got next Tuesday pulled up, how does the afternoon look?
agostina_brief_pitch.note: Name-dropping the cleaners (Vanessa, Bectali, Emily) shows you've done your homework. Emphasize no workflow change — that's critical for an ops person managing in-house staff. Then book the meeting.

branches.label: I'd need to loop in Nick or Elisa

book_meeting_agostina.label: BOOK MEETING WITH AGOSTINA
book_meeting_agostina.say: I'd love to show you how this works — takes about fifteen minutes and worst case you steal some ideas from what other PMs in North County are doing with their turnover photos. I've got next Tuesday afternoon open — does that work for you?
book_meeting_agostina.note: Lock in the meeting NOW. Suggest a specific day and time. If she needs founders involved, offer to include them on the invite.

branches.label: Need to loop in Nick or Elisa

agostina_have_process.label: AGOSTINA — WE HAVE A PROCESS
agostina_have_process.say: That totally makes sense — with fifty-plus homes you'd have to have something locked in. I'm not trying to replace your process at all — more like an extra layer on top. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again though — is it that you're fully covered and happy with how things are working, or is it more that adding anything new right now would just be a headache?
agostina_have_process.note: Miyagi method. Agree first. Then split the objection. If she's happy, respect it. If switching is the headache, sell the test drive — no workflow change required.

branches.label: Opens up about gaps in their process

agostina_objection.label: AGOSTINA — NOT INTERESTED
agostina_objection.say: Totally get that — I should've assumed you'd be all set, otherwise you probably would've reached out yourself. Just so no one from my team calls you again — is it that turnover quality isn't really a focus right now, or is it more that you just hate cold calls? Because honestly I get it either way.
agostina_objection.note: Miyagi method. Don't push. Split the objection. If she hates cold calls, acknowledge it and offer email. If it's not a priority, plant a seed and exit cleanly.

branches.label: It's not a priority right now

agostina_reschedule.label: AGOSTINA — BAD TIMING
agostina_reschedule.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow morning? I'll keep it to two minutes, promise.
agostina_reschedule.note: Get a specific callback time. Even a vague 'try tomorrow' is better than nothing.

sell_test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
sell_test_drive.say: That's the best part honestly — there's literally no switching involved. It layers right on top of whatever you're already doing. Your cleaners keep taking photos the same way they always do — we just analyze them. Could I show you a quick fifteen-minute demo? Even if it's not for right now, worst case you see what other managers are doing with their turnover photos and you steal some ideas.
sell_test_drive.note: No workflow change is the killer differentiator for ops people. They're terrified of disrupting what works for their cleaning team. Emphasize the 'layer on top' angle hard.

loop_in_founders.label: LOOP IN FOUNDERS
loop_in_founders.say: One hundred percent — makes total sense to have them in the room. Would it work to set up a quick fifteen minutes with you and Nick or Elisa? I can send over an invite right now — how does next week look?
loop_in_founders.note: This is ideal — getting a meeting with the decision maker AND the ops person in one shot. Push for a specific day. If she defers, ask if she can introduce you via email.

branches.label: Let me check with them first
Just reach out to them directly

got_founders_from_agostina.label: AGOSTINA REFERS TO FOUNDERS
got_founders_from_agostina.say: Got it — would you mind shooting Nick or Elisa a quick note that Sam from RapidEye is going to reach out? Even a one-liner would go a long way. I'll keep it short with them.
got_founders_from_agostina.note: Getting an email intro from Agostina to the founders is the best possible outcome short of booking a meeting. Push gently for it.

send_email_agostina.label: SEND EMAIL TO AGOSTINA
send_email_agostina.say: Totally fair. One quick question before I do — what would be most relevant to include so it's not just another generic pitch in your inbox? Like is it more about the cost side, or more about how it actually works alongside what you're already doing?
send_email_agostina.note: Accept it gracefully, then ask what to include. This tells you her priority. Most likely email: agostina@haustay.com based on Haustay's pattern (nick@, elisa@). Include 2-3 specific time slots in the email.

branches.label: Gives guidance on what to include

confirm_email_agostina.label: CONFIRM AGOSTINA'S EMAIL
confirm_email_agostina.say: Got it — I'll put something together today. What's the best email for you? And I'll drop in a couple times to chat in case you want to dig in after you read it.
confirm_email_agostina.note: Confirm her email. If she gives agostina@haustay.com, great. If she gives something else, note it. Follow up in 2 days if no response.

send_email_founders.label: SEND EMAIL TO FOUNDERS
send_email_founders.say: Got it. Is nick@haustay.com still the best way to reach Nick? I'll send something short and specific so it doesn't get buried. Really appreciate the pointer, Agostina.
send_email_founders.note: Casually confirm the email. You already know it's nick@haustay.com. If she corrects it, even better — you got the real one.

respect_and_plant_seed.label: RESPECT AND PLANT SEED
respect_and_plant_seed.say: Totally respect that. Hey — if anything changes, especially heading into summer when the turnover volume picks up, I'm easy to find. Sam Parks, RapidEye. Really appreciate your time.
respect_and_plant_seed.note: Don't burn the bridge. San Diego's peak vacation season is summer. Plant the seed for when volume increases and things start slipping through. Note the outcome and try Nick or Elisa directly on a separate call.

warm_referral.label: WARM REFERRAL PATH
warm_referral.say: Oh that's great — who mentioned it? I want to make sure I'm connecting with the right people over there.
warm_referral.note: If someone at Haustay actually mentioned RapidEye, this changes everything. Find out who and what they said, then ask to be connected to that person.

suggest_time.label: SUGGEST SPECIFIC TIME
suggest_time.say: How about next Tuesday at two? Takes about fifteen minutes. I'll send the invite right now while I've got you.
suggest_time.note: Be specific. Pick a day and time. Send the calendar invite while still on the phone so it's locked in before she can reconsider.

confirm_meeting.label: CONFIRM MEETING
confirm_meeting.say: Perfect — sending the invite right now. It'll come from sam@rapideye.ai. Really appreciate you taking my call. Talk soon.
confirm_meeting.note: STOP SELLING. Lock it in, confirm the email for the invite, and get off the phone. Don't give them a reason to second-guess.

referral_confirmed.label: REFERRAL CONFIRMED
referral_confirmed.say: You're awesome — thank you, Bectali. I'll reach out to them and keep it short. Really appreciate your help. Have a good one.
referral_confirmed.note: End warmly. Bectali just turned your next call from cold to warm. Write down everything she told you about the inspection process — it's ammunition for the decision-maker call. Call the referred person within 24 hours while the mention is fresh.

try_main_line.label: TRY MAIN LINE
try_main_line.say: Got it — I'll try the main line. Hey Bectali, I really appreciate your time. If my name comes up around the office, it's Sam with RapidEye — we help with the inspection side of turnovers. Thanks again and have a good one.
try_main_line.note: Main line is (858) 522-9127. Call back and ask for Agostina or Nick by first name. Use the slide-by gatekeeper approach: 'Could you get me through to Agostina? It's Sam.'

end_graceful.label: END GRACEFULLY
end_graceful.say: Totally understand. Hey — really appreciate your time, Bectali. If anything ever comes up around inspections or turnovers, I'm easy to find. Sam Parks, RapidEye. Have a good one.
end_graceful.note: Don't burn the bridge. She talks to the founders and Agostina daily — a good impression here can pay off later. Follow up by calling the main line and trying to reach Agostina or Nick directly.
